description: The objective of Rolaball is simple: Move your ball on the isometric landscape guarded by baddies, pick up the crosses and go for the exit. After you clear the first few levels, the game becomes more involved, with each level having several exits, some of which teleport you between different platforms without any natural collection. Though this might look and sound like Marble Madness, that is not the case, since the ball is moved in steps between tiles and without any inertia.

sample_screenshots.caption: Pick up the crosses and then go to the circle
You start out at the bottom of the first level
Teleportation spots all over the place

title: Rola-Ball

description:
Just like Cavern Fighter, Cave Fighter is a Scramble clone.

Your objective is to fly your little spaceship unscathed through a cave system. As you fly, missiles will fly up from the ground to intercept, but they can be shot down. As you shoot, you also drop bombs, which allows you to destroy the fuel canisters planted on the ground, and thereby replenish your energy supply. A further distraction comes in the shape of bars that block the cave. You must shoot holes in the bars to pass through. Everything scrolls at a high speed, which makes for very hectic gameplay.

The game features a very small sprite, only one character tall, four-colour graphics and a title screen with sampled speech.

sample_screenshots.caption: You must shoot your way through these walls
The screen flashes as you die
Due to the flickering, you won't see much of the plane in screenshots

title: Cave Fighter

description: With a name like that, what can one expect, save an isometric shooter with heavy Zaxxon influences? Yet, even though Zak's Son makes no attempt to hide its influences, it doesn't slavishly mimic its role model. Unlike Zaxxon, you are flying a helicopter, and this game entirely lacks the concept of height above ground. Any shots fired will hit whatever it crosses, be it on ground or airbourne. You also have your fuel level to keep an eye on. By shooting canisters marked with an F, you replenish your dwindling fuel supply. Failure to do so results in game over, and so does the loss of your three lives. The game plays entirely in black and white high resolution mode.

sample_screenshots.caption: The screen flashes as you die
After a while, fighter plane attack waves appear
If I don't shoot this fuel icon...
These turrets are harmless. Perhaps they aren't turrets.

title: Zak's Son

description: Bust-out! is a game in the Breakout vein, where you use a paddle to reflect a ball against bricks, with the goal of smashing all those bricks. This version has a range of options, such as two collision detection schemes, variable size of bricks and paddle, background music and speed. The game is executed entirely in low-resolution graphics mode, which might explain the unorthodox collision detection; you will find that your ball might dig a path straight through the entire brick wall in one bounce.

sample_screenshots.caption: This kind of thing usually doesn't occur in other Breakout games
The ball bounces aginst the score readout!

title: Bust-out!

description:
You're the chief engineer of the spaceship "Hooray Henry". Whilst on a trial run, the new engine breaks down, and in order to keep your captain Dr. Bug-eyes from losing face, your task is to mend the system so that you can come back without being towed back.

In a number of screens, varying in intricacy according to difficulty level, you must guide a lone pixel across the surrealistic screens that are the engine room to a green sphere, from which you go on to the next screen. The mission must be accomplished within a time limit, and your time is the basis for your final score. The movement of the dot is not very straight-forward, since the cursor keys do not match the diagonal movements of the dot. If you run into an obstacle, you will bounce of that and must correct your trajectory again.

The game is written in BASIC, which means some waiting as each screen is being drawn.

sample_screenshots.caption: You are the small yellow dot
The real challenge is to do it in as little time as possible

title: Antigravity

description: Star Fighter is a rather generic side-scrolling shoot'em'up with certain Scramble influences. Your plane travels across an undulating landscape where aliens sit at the ground. You can strafe down and shoot them on the ground, or wait until they lift off and fly into your line of sight. Your beam is short and thin, so precision is required in order to hit them before they fly into you. The game starts off in four-colour mode, then switches to black and white high resolution mode, possibly to simulate night flight. Three game speeds are available, and the screen scrolls fast, even at the slowest setting. Unlike the vast majority of games, it scrolls from left to right, instead of the opposite. Due to the use of analogue joysticks, and the speed of your ship, there is a lot of inertia in your control, which feels more realistic than the straight course in which you travel in other similar games.

sample_screenshots.caption: You fly into the empty screen
The screen flashes as it crashes
After a while, the screen turns black

title: Star Fighter

description:
Total Eclipse takes its basic concept from Elite (which was never ported to the Dragon) but moves focus from real-time space flight to the trading and navigation aspects.

The game is played through a series of graphical menus, joined by 3D and 2D action sequences. It takes place in a universe made up of 12 galaxies divided into 10 sectors of 36 cells (a total of 4 320 cells). Despite taking place in space, the galaxy map is two-dimensional. The cells may contain empty space, space stations, planets, asteroids, hypergates, black holes and abandoned space cruisers.

You start out on a space station, which offer refueling and repair as well as investment services (recommended only for rich players). Planets vary in technological level and political system. Travel to anarchistic planets should be avoided by inexperienced players. Though all planets offer trading and refueling facilities, services such as repairs and spare parts (as well as the kind of spares) are dependent on the technological level of the planets. This also governs the range of goods on the stock market, and their prices. Asteroids can be mined for asteroil, a sought-after substance which may be traded at stations. Hypergates facilitate travel to other galaxies. Black holes are generally dangerous and should be avoided, though the manual hints at other possibilities. The abandoned space cruisers may be visited for claiming salvage money. To do so, you must enter the ship, find the bridge, take the captain's log, and return to your ship before the self-destruct sequence is activated.

Using the short scanner, you may scan 36 cells in your vicinity and identify their contents. Each scan uses up your computer energy level, ultimately leading to operation failure. It is therefore necessary to reload your computer just as you refuel your ship. Upgrading the RAM of your ship computer activates the long-range scanner, which enables a longer scanning radius and hence a longer operation radius, since all travel is initiated from the scanner menu. A further RAM upgrade opens up the data scanner menu, which can scan an entire galaxy at once.

When you reach a planet, pirates may try to extort you for protection money. Failing to pay may incur pirate attacks in space, which are fought out in a 3D view where you move your crosshairs to try to shoot down the attacking ships. In case the enemy is at an advantage, you can try to out-run them, or alternatively attempt a panic hyperjump, which moves you instantaneously to a random position elsewhere in the galaxy, with a chance of survival of 66.6%. Destroying a pirate ship will release its cargo into space, which will be transported to your vessel.

Due to space constraints, the system of Total Eclipse can't be described in further detail, though it is at least as involved as Elite.
title: Total Eclipse

description:
From Microdeal's budget label comes a maze exploration/survival game with similarities to older arcade titles. As you start the game (after the title screen which plays a rendition of The Entertainer, the screen quickly flashes an overhead map of the five levels of a dungeon, after which you find yourself at the middle level.

You move your character in block increments through the dungeon, with the objective to find nine pieces of an ancient shield that are scattered throughout the five levels. You are working against time, since a gauge on the right side of the screen is running down, which can be interpreted as oxygen supply, stamina or a simple time limit. When the gauge is depleted, you lose one of your three lives. Another way to lose a life is to run into one of the blobby monsters that wander around in the depths. Fortunately, you are not unarmed. If you find yourself on the same horizontal level as a monster, you may fire your boomerang, which bounces back to you after hitting a monster or a wall. This is especially powerful in case the maze is filled with monsters, since the boomerang may very well take down several at once if they enter the right level at the right time. However, the boomerang can only be fired horizontally, not vertically.

The game offers the usual Dragon colour selections: Black and white, buff or green.

sample_screenshots.caption: Found a piece of the shield

title: Pit Fiend

description: This Space Invaders variant, simply called Space Invaders, has very little to differentiate itself from the Taito original. It has the rows of aliens, the three barriers, your ship that can only fire one bullet at a time, and the flying saucer that passes by from time to time. What is lacking is the accelerating "heartbeat" sound and the changing colours of the invaders. The game has, somewhat uncommon for space games, a white background with an orange ship, cyan invaders and magenta barriers. Nine difficulty levels are available.

sample_screenshots.caption: Now they are few but deadly close and deadly fast!

title: Space Invaders

description: Jump Jet let's you fly the pride of the British navy, the Harrier VTOL fighter, across sea and land in order to fulfill a dangerous mission. The game plays in a side-scrolling shoot'em'up fashion. After lift-off from your base, your plane is attacked by enemy planes which must naturally be shot down. After crossing the sea and the mountains, you must attack a fortified island. Unlike normal sidescrollers, your plane actually flies faster than the chunky scrolling, making it reappear at the left end of the screen once it has reached the right side. An indicator at the bottom shows the status of your mission, whereas scores, levels and munitions levels are accounted for at the top. Much of the game is written in BASIC.
title: Jump Jet

description:
Destroy all eggs!

With that as your only instructions, you are thrown into a room filled with pterodactyl eggs. The controls are similar to many versions of Robotron, in that you shoot in whichever direction you are walking. The task of destroying the eggs seems easy until they begin to hatch. The new-born pterodactyls are not only lethal, but they lay more eggs, prolonging your misery.

The game runs in black and white high resolution mode and uses small characters, only a character tall.

sample_screenshots.caption: The pterodactyl will lay more eggs unless you kill it

title: Pterodactyl

description:
Laser Run owes its entire gameplay to the sequence of the Star Wars arcade game where you fly through a trench on the Death Star with the ultimate goal of shooting into a vent leading to the main reactor of the weapon. In fact, this blatant copy even plays the theme from Star Wars on the title screen.

Since there is not much point in steering your ship while it runs down a straight trench, you instead control the crosshairs of your gun so that you can shoot down the TIE fighters that come flying in your opposite direction. The first fighter waves leave you alone, but soon they start to fire at you. When you encounter the hole in the trench, you must shoot into it – not in order to destroy the Death Star, but so as to replenish your shield energy. Two gauges on the screen show your remaining energy level and the distance to the next hole.

sample_screenshots.caption: A TIE fighter comes at you

title: Laser Run

description:
Lucifer's Kingdom is one of the rare vertically scrolling shoot'em'ups for the Dragon 32. In order to achieve smooth scrolling, the play area is limited to a block roughly half the size of the screen, with the rest of the screen area dedicated to score and status displays.

The game borrows basic looks, though not as much mechanism, from Tehkan's influential Star Force, ranging from the starting ramp which marks the beginning of the level, to the looks of the enemy waves and the chunks of ground floating in space, filled with squares marked with the letter B. Another obvious influence is that the areas of the game are named after letters in the Greek alphabet. One trait that sets Lucifer's Kingdom apart, however, is that you collect crystals (xtals), which is done by repeatedly shooting the bricks marked C until they give away and release a crystal.

sample_screenshots.caption: Nearing the end of the level

title: Lucifer's Kingdom

description: Super Lander is your typical moon lander game, of the kind of which every computer must have at least a dozen, especially during its formative years. Your goal is to land your moon lander on a landing pad without crashing into the ground. Your enemies are only gravity and the inertia from your thrusters. Two landing pads are available, depending on your level of expertise.
title: Super Lander

description: You are a small man living in a protective bubble. Your job is to clear the aquatic screen from the swarming creatures which inhabit it. You can shoot in the horizontal direction in which you are pointing, but turning from left to right or right to left takes time due to the inertia of the fluid which seems to make up the screen. You also need to compensate for gravity now and then, or you will sink to the bottom. The bottom, like all other edges of the screen, is deadly and will burst your bubble. Prolonged contact with the creatures will have the same effect. Each screen is started out on your base, where you can sit, protected by a forcefield, until you find the right time to leave its safety, or until the field runs out of force.
title: Home Base

description:
The protagonist of this game, who looks like one of those head-on-feet characters which three-year-olds tend to draw, is the subject of a cruel experiment. Level after level, he is locked inside a maze and must get out before his willpower reaches zero. This means that you will have to find all the necessary keys for locking up the exit, and these are spread all over the maze, of which only one room can be seen at a time. Try to find the map, it will facilitate easier navigation, but each time you look at it time will run much faster, giving you a lower score. The maze is filled with certain dangers, in the guise of snakes which will eat you alive if you startle them. Try to avoid their rooms, or cross them quickly when they turn away from your direction. Finding items such as keys, food or maps will keep your willpower up.

The game runs in medium resolution in four colours and features a 3D animation top view of your character as well as animated sequences between levels.

sample_screenshots.caption: The new maze requires more keys
As can be evidenced by this corridor, the new maze is larger

title: Back Track

description:
In this simple pinball game, written in BASIC, you have one table. You earn basic points for bouncing on items, but you must hit the letters D-R-A-G-O-N in order to raise your bonus multiplier. Hitting the red parts jutting out from the left and right sides of the table makes reconfigures the part of the table below the letters, which will alter the ball's direction when entering the letter channel. In the upper right corner, there is a channel filled with white colour, and when all the white colour has been bounced away, you earn your bonus instantly. For every 2500 points, you earn an extra ball.

The game uses a "semigraphics" mode, forfeiting all use of detailed graphics, and makes the ball's movement very jaggy.
title: Pinball

description:
Not as action-oriented as the more well-known School Daze, this is a primitive semigraphical adventure made in BASIC.

Your mission is to retrieve an important computer tape that has been lost somewhere in the school. You first find yourself represented by a small character on a map of the school, and must go to the entrance of the school office to get a pass, after which you are free to move from room to room.

Moving between rooms, while searching for clues, means pressing keys representing directions. Each room is illustrated using character block graphics, and some have special functions, such as the music room, where you can play notes on the keyboard, or the lunch room where you can eat. Moving around in the school without seeing the map can prove quite disorientating, since moving north and then south doesn't necessarily mean that you will end up in the same place.

sample_screenshots.caption: The map of the school; you're represented by the green arrow thing

title: School Maze

description: Desperado Dan must escape to freedom, being trapped in a set of green-screen platform levels. Each screen is guarded not only by guards, but also by a cannon which fires a single bouncing ball to be avoided. Dan must jump across all the obstacles, but luckily, he can leap very far. Another obstacle are the animated doors which open and close. As you progress through the game, the motifs change. Dan must mount a jet-ski and jump over whales and octopuses, but the controls and mechanisms remain basically the same, although the screens become even more crowded and faster.

sample_screenshots.caption: On later screens, the theme changes to an aquatic one

title: Desperado Dan and His Amazing Escape to Freedom

description:
Naturally, this is a clone of the ever-popular Boulder Dash, only for the Dragon 32.

Like in its role model, you are a miner-type person digging your way around tile by tile in some kind of underground complex filled with boulders and crystals. You must collect a set number of crystals to clear a level. The level wraps around at the borders, so it's easy to get lost.

As you dig through the earth, you must watch out when you pass below boulders, since these can drop down at you. If there is a mass of boulders, you can start a rockslide which can very well kill you. On the other hand, these rock slides are often a necessity if you are to reach crystals jammed between the boulders. Digging the correct canals to channel the boulders into is an essential part of the game's strategy.

The game runs entirely in monochrome high resolution mode and allows you to play against the clock and choose levels with some freedom.

sample_screenshots.caption: You can easily get killed in a rockslide

title: Boulder Crash

description: As you can deduce from the name, this is a blatant copy of First Star's classic Spy vs. Spy. You, and optionally another player, run around a house on a split screen, your goal being to find the keys required to escape the house. You can also plant traps for your opponent to fall into. The game runs in 4-colour medium resolution mode.
title: Spy against Spy

description:
A colourful arcade game, Boris the Bold has you guiding the face-with-legs called Boris around a series of platform levels. There is a moving gap in each floor for Boris to fall through, so that he can reach the exit at the bottom of the screen. Boris must walk to the hole or wait until it reaches him, but waiting can be dangerous, since there is a bouncing ball hunting him. As if the ball wasn't enough, there are additional nasties patrolling certain floors back and forth, and batteries which will fire at Boris if he remains in the same place for too long.

Boris has no offensive measures, but he can "hyperjump" to a random location on the floor he is standing on, or alternatively to the floor immediately above him. Due to the random nature of the hyperjumps, though, Boris can end up straight next to another enemy.

sample_screenshots.caption: Will the gap reach Boris before the ball?

title: Boris the Bold

description:
Copta Snatch plays much like Konami's Super Cobra, only the helicopter you're controlling actually works a little more like a real helicopter. No more forced scrolling; here you can hover above a target or strafe back and forth above the landscape. Hovering lets you drop bombs, otherwise you fire forwards in the direction you're travelling.

The landscape is littered with missile silos and anti-aircraft guns which fire at you at the slightest chance. You also have to keep an eye on your fuel level – when you're running out, you must find a refueling pad to land on. These pads also serve as your starting points when you've died.

Copta Snatch uses a quite uncommon "semigraphics" mode to great effect, similar to the Tandy title Protector II.

sample_screenshots.caption: Here's the older, less pretty loading screen
Ground-to-air missiles and some even bigger rockets
Starting out on your home base

title: Copta Snatch

description: Probably the first version of Tetris for the Dragon, this game replicates well the standard gameplay of the well-known Soviet game (although it does not appear to be an "official" port). The graphics use a semigraphics mode, with the falling blocks rendered with a special striped effect to achieve unusual colour tones. A bit of sampled speech is also included, with the game proclaiming "Tetris!" when you eliminate four rows at once. High scores can be saved and loaded to disk.

sample_screenshots.caption: A sampled voice says "Tetris!" when you land the leftmost block

title: Tetris

description: An implementation of the solitaire mahjongg game, as popularised by Activision's Shanghai, Paul Burgin's Shanghai requires you to eliminate all the mahjongg tiles from the screen by finding matching pairs, though only tiles on the outer edges can be matched up, which requires a lot of planning ahead and good memory. Monochrome graphics are used to display the tiles, and the game is terminated when no more matching tiles can be found. Unlike some other implementations of this game, only one layout is available.

sample_screenshots.caption: The tiles at the start of the game

title: Shanghai

description: As a football simulation, Crazy Foota is closer to table football games than to the actual sport. The 11 players of each team stand lined up against the left and right edges of the screen, selected by moving the joystick up or down. The selected player can only move horizontally, trying to catch the ball which at the beginning of the game bounces up and down in the middle of the field. The ball sticks to the foot of the player who catches it, and can be kicked in any direction chosen with the joystick. The game runs entirely in black and white.
title: Crazy Foota

description:
You are a helicopter pilot sent out to rescue survivors from a troop ship crashed into enemy waters. The game is made out of two screens.

The first screen plays like Asteroids, without the splitting asteroids. Shoot down enemy ships and avoid their fire, while you look for survivors. The men don't show up on the screen, instead you have to follow the coordinates at the bottom of the screen. When in the vicinity of the correct coordinates, press the S button, and you reach the second screen.

The second screen is seen from the side, your helicopter hovering above the sea surface with a ladder hanging out to pick up the floating men. The waters are patrolled by a man-eating shark, though, so hurry up or it will be well-fed. You have a small number of bombs that you can drop on the shark.

The first screen is played with the keyboard, whereas the second uses the joystick. Both use four-colour medium resolution graphics.

sample_screenshots.caption: And then it's more of the same...
Dropping a bomb on the sharp

title: Jaws!

description: City Defence is a variant of Missile Command. You have a laser turret on the ground, as the sole line of defence against incoming ballistic missiles. Using the joystick, you must guide your cross hairs at the warheads and push the button to shoot them down before they hit one of your six cities. Your aim must be exact to hit the missiles themselves, and more points are awarded for more exact hits. High scores give you extra cities, and the game is over when all are destroyed. Somewhat strangely, even missile hits on the grounds of a destroyed city counts, which will lead to game over even when there are cities remaining.

sample_screenshots.caption: The screen turns green and the city is destroyed in a blazing red circle

title: City Defence

description:
Trun is a series of small games made famous by the movie Tron:

  • Cycles is a ”light cycles” game where you draw a line and must trap the opponent inside that line, without colliding with his line.

  • Cone puts you in a cramped space where you must shoot moving blocks so that you can advance until you reach the cone at the top of the screen. If you don't advance, you will be hit in the back by an advancing bar, and if you don't shoot the blocks, you will be hit by those instead.

  • Tanks presents a top-down view of a maze, where you must guide your tank and shoot the opposing tanks.

  • Spiders consists of a screen filled with spiders. Move your little man and try to shoot all the spiders (only one shot can be on the screen at any time, so aim carefully) and then proceed to the exit before the time is out.

As you finish all four games, selectable from a menu, you progress to the next level with more and harder enemies.
title: Trun

description: Bandito is a simulation of a one-armed bandit, with some bells and whistles. Starting out with £1, you pay 10 pence for each pull at the bandit's arm. Depending on what comes up, you may be able to ”hold” some of the cylinders in order to increase chances of a winning combination. On some occasions, or when you get three lemons, you can ”nudge” the cylinders to piece together a winning line. Finally, it is possible to ”gamble” with your bonus, or to simply collect it as it is.

sample_screenshots.caption: You can choose to "hold" some fruits

title: Bandito

description: Snakes can be described as a simplistic variation on the Centipede theme, crossed with the obscure Atari VCS game Sssnake. You move your little man around on a screen populated by a few spade-like mushrooms, when from the borders, a snake slithers onto the screen. The snake steams straight ahead until it bumps into a wall or a mushroom, in which case it makes a turn. You can shoot the snake and make it disappear, but only if you hit its head, which requires precise timing. If you wait for too long, more and more snakes enter the screen, and sooner or later you will collide with one of them, and it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: There are too many of them!
You hit one on the head

title: Snakes

description: In this text adventure, you play the friend of a professor who has gone missing on some kind of archaeological survey. Your task is to find the professor, or at least to find out his fate. On your adventure, you will ride the taxi a lot (and must find a way to pay the driver), travel by airplane and visit a remote, mysterious island. The command interpreter is of a rather simple verb-noun mould, with some peculiarities such as SAYing your wishes to the taxi driver.

sample_screenshots.caption: You start out in the study

title: Raiders

description: This computer translation of the board game is restricted to solitary play against the computer, Red being the player and Blue the opponent. It is however possible to let the machine handle a player's turn if so desired, which means it will effectively play against itself if this is done continuously. Games are played singly, there's no match score and doubling cube.
title: Backgammon

description: Dragon Trek is a commercial variant of the Star Trek game that originally appeared on mainframe computers. At the start, the difficulty and length of the game (determining the size of the galaxy) can be selected. The player then takes command of the starship Enterprise, trying to eliminate a specific number of Klingon ships using phasers or photon torpedoes. Phasers have three different range settings, the longer the distance, the more energy is consumed for a shot. Movement at impulse speed is done with joystick control, the keyboard is used for command input. To travel to different quadrants faster, the warp engines are used. The scanners of the Enterprise are limited in their capabilities, to get information about the contents of a quadrant, a hyperprobe may be launched if necessary. In addition to friendly starbases which can be docked for faster damage repair and supplies, a quadrant may also contain hazards other than the Klingons, like black holes.

sample_screenshots.caption: Tactical status display showing the area nearby

title: Dragon Trek

description:
Eddie Steady Go! is a sequel to Back Track. After having escaped the labyrinths of Back Track, Eddie once again finds himself in trouble as he is recaptured by the mad professor. The professor has built a 22 part obstacle course which Eddie has to make his way through. The game consists of 22 single screen platform levels and the objective is simply to move Eddie from the left to the right side of the screen without being killed — very much like Hunchback. The controls are simple as all Eddie can do is move left, right and jump. The player has to watch out for arrows, rolling boulders, falling rocks and other objects that instantly kills Eddie when making contact. Eddie can also die by falling too far.

Once all 22 levels have been completed the game restarts at a higher speed. There are three speeds so the total number of levels is 66. The player earns points as he make it through the levels and can get bonuses by picking up and eating apples. After 10,000 points or completing all 22 levels extra lives are earned. From the start the player has nine lives.

sample_screenshots.caption: Fourth level - jump over the rolling boulders
Second level - watch out for the arrow
Sixth level - more boulders, but this time they come from behind

title: Eddie Steady Go!

description: The Alien Bongo Beast leader, in his quest to wipe out everything honest, decent and generally nice, has constructed a demolition machine, called the Balldozer, to destroy all the æstethic brickwork on planet Barrat'omes. What this boils down to is a monochrome Breakout variant with a lot of Arkanoid amenities in the form of upgrades such as sticky bat, hard ball and speed modifiers. The blocks also come in different levels of hardness, requiring one or several hits to break. Since the ball picks up pace quickly, picking up the often-released slow-down items is a necessity.

sample_screenshots.caption: If you get the ball in here, you can go for a coffee break
Some bricks are tougher than others

title: Balldozer

description:
Dirk Bronzetorso, a normal if rather tasteless Englishman, discovers an invoice upon his return home. He has forgotten to pay his gas bill, and now has only 24 hours to do so, or the Alien Bongo Beast, head of bill payments (and known from Balldozer) will transport him to the criss-crossy lines dimension, where he must fight millions of baddies. Unfortunately, Dirk is attacked by an axe-wielding aubergine in his fridge, and lacking all his limbs, he doesn't manage to pay the bill on time. Thus begins Dirk's adventures in the criss-crossy lines dimension.

The criss-crossy lines turn out to be the grid backdrop of this omnidirectionally scrolling shoot'em'up in monochrome screen mode. While attacked from all directions, you must destroy eight generator vents to disable the defence systems of the level. Before you can progress to the next one, you must fight a boss. The controls are similar to Bosconian, working in eight directions, but with an additional thrust button as in Asteroids. At your disposal, you have both a gun and missiles.
title: ROTABB: Revenge Of The Alien Bongo Beast in the Criss-Crossy Lines Dimension

description:
In UXB the player is given the task of defusing an old unexploded war-time bomb. The game is menu based and played with keyboard. First the player has to choose the right items from his toolkit. Due to limited space in the vicinity of the bomb he can only carry six of these twelve items: small spanner, copper hammer, cold chisel, special fluid, sidecutters, stethoscope, socket set, pliers, hydraulic jack, special spanner, insulating tape and small screwdriver. If the player picks more than six items the bomb will go off right away. There is no way to dump an item so it's necessary to pick the right ones from the start. Before starting to work, the bomb can be examined from three views: side, nose and hatch.

When working on the bomb the player is presented with a menu of five options (for example move bomb or unscrew nosecap). The player has to pick the right option and then the right tool. Picking the wrong combination leads to the bomb going off while picking the right one leads to the player advancing to the next menu (with new options) and everything repeats until the bomb has been defused. If stuck the player can type HELP to get a hint on how to proceed. When the bomb goes off the player is given the choice to restart from the last move or from the beginning.

sample_screenshots.caption: All the tools you can choose from

title: UXB

description: Airball Construction Kit not only lets you transfer Airball from cassette tape to floppy disk, but also allows you to reconstruct levels or construct levels of your own.
title: Airball Construction Kit

description: JSW Screen Designer starts out by letting you transfer the tape-only Jet Set Willy to disk, and, as its main attraction, lets you design new levels for the classic platformer.
title: Jet Set Willy Screen Designer

description:
The Sword and the Sorcerer is a dungeon crawler set in a maze consisting of 225 locations that the player has to explore, one screen at a time, with the aim of making it out in one piece. To succeed with that it's necessary to collect three pieces of a key and to locate a bolted door to escape through. In the maze the player will come across more or less dangerous creatures (there are nineteen in total) and he will also find weapons (thirteen different ones), gold, potions and food.

The game is entirely controlled with the keyboard and all actions are available from a menu and the player has to enter the corresponding number. To get past a creature the player either has to attack it, bribe it or trade with it. For each attack the enemy and the player will lose some strength and the player has to keep entering the command until the enemy has died. If losing the player can choose to run away but it will cost five strength points. Strength is also decreased by one for every move made in the maze but it's possible to recharge it by eating food or drinking potions. The player has an inventory for eight items and of those one offensive and one defensive weapon can be equipped. Different weapons do different damage on different enemies.
title: The Sword and the Sorcerer

description: St George and the Dragons is a single screen action game where the player controls the saint. A wizard has imprisoned a number of maidens in an enchanted castle and it's up to George to free them. The spell of the castle is tied to a rock and to free the maidens George has to use his sword to cleave the rock. The rock is located in the bottom left corner of the screen and to reach it George must use a bridge to cross a river. At the same time it's necessary to avoid or kill the fire breathing dragon that is hunting the hero. Getting hit by the dragon's fire or running into the water leads to a life being lost. Once the rock has been hit by the sword the level is completed and the player earns one point and moves on to another level which works exactly the same way.

sample_screenshots.caption: Game over and the game gets a bit rude

title: St George and the Dragons

description: Skier is an alpine skiing game. The game is viewed from a bird's-eye perspective and scrolls from the top to the bottom. After starting out, the skier automatically descends down the slope and the player's control is limited to moving left and right with the joystick. The aim of the game is simply to earn points by skiing through the slalom gates that appear. The slope has two different obstacles that have to be avoided: tree trunks and rocks. A game can be played by one or two players who each make five runs. Hitting an obstacle causes the current run to be abandoned. At the end of the fifth run the player with the highest total score wins.

sample_screenshots.caption: Skiing dangerously close to a tree

title: Skier

description:
Folly Farm's Chicken Run is a single screen platform game where a hen has to lay eggs that then have to be collected by a farmer. The player is in control of both the hen and the farmer. The screen consists of five platforms that the hen can walk across and fly between. On the left side of each platform is a nest box and to the right there is a corn tray. The hen automatically lays an egg when moving over the nest box and pecks corn when next to the tray. Pecking corn restores the energy level of the hen to prevent it from starving to death. On each platform is also a hole that a fox can enter from. The fox has to be avoided or it will kill the hen.

On the sides of the screen are two ladders that the farmer climbs up and down. The player doesn't directly control the farmer but can open flaps on the sides of each platform. If the farmer passes a nest box with an egg that has its flap open, he will collect the egg and transport it to the right side where it is dropped into an egg box. The farmer also refills the corn trays from the ladder on the right side but only if the right flap is open. If the farmer doesn't collect an egg quick enough a chick will hatch and start pecking away at the nearest corn tray. The chicks too can get killed by the fox.

sample_screenshots.caption: The hen can fly between platforms

title: Folly Farm's Chicken Run

description: Mission XK1 is a variant of the arcade game Lunar Rescue. The player is in control of a lander whose task it is to land on the planet Zyphon where it has to collect fuel. The player is dropped from a mother ship at the top of the screen and has to navigate through an asteroid field with the aim of landing on one of three pads on the surface. While moving down thrust controls are used to steer the lander and slow down its descent but if to too much thrust is used it will run out of fuel. After collecting the fuel the player has to fly back up to the mother ship. While doing so it is possible to shoot and destroy the asteroids. Lives are lost when crashing into the ground or the asteroids or when missing the mother ship.

sample_screenshots.caption: Using thrust to slow down the descent
Attempting to land on the centre pad

title: Mission XK1

description: Karma Carzy is a variant of the arcade racing game Rally-X. The game is set in a maze that is 36 screens in size. The aim is to collect ten flags that are scattered around the maze while avoiding the AI controlled cars that chase and attempt to crash into the player. In the maze, there are fuel tanks that need to be collected or the car's fuel might run out. To delay the chaser cars, the player is able to release smoke from the exhaust. The amount of smoke that can be used is dependent on the level. There are ten levels, with later levels featuring more cars and boulders blocking the path. The game ends when the player has run out of all three lives by crashing or running out of fuel.

sample_screenshots.caption: Chaser car gets trapped in smoke

title: Karma Carzy

description:
Castle of Doom is a text adventure with graphics that show corridors from a first person perspective. The objective of the game is to find and kill a vampire called Count Doom. The adventure starts in the House of Doom which the player has to find a way out from. It contains 27 locations and is followed by the Doom Town which has a further 36 locations. Finally the player has to enter the Castle of Doom which has another 27 locations.

Like in other text adventures the game is played by entering verb noun commands. When entering a location the player first sees a full screen view of it and upon pressing the space bar a text prompt appears where commands can be entered. On the text screen the player can also see directions that can be moved in as well as objects that can be interacted with. All objects are randomly places around the locations. Using the look command redraws the image while the listen command gives information about the location's sound. If stuck, a help command can be used for a hint.
title: Castle of Doom

description:
Sporting Decathlon is a sports game that involves competing in all the ten events of a real decathlon competition: 200 metres hurdles, 100 metres, javelin, 400 metres, shot putt, pole vault, high jump, 1500 metres, discus and long jump. The events are played in order and for each one points are earned with medals being awarded at the end. All events are viewed from a side view perspective.

Running is done with two buttons (speed up and slow down) and a third button is used for jumping or throwing. In running events the player has an energy rating which is not allowed to reach zero since the race will then be abandoned. A high pace leads to more energy being burned and therefore it is necessary to not run faster than what's needed to win the race. Throwing events only involve holding down a button to set the strength and then release it at the right time. The jumping events are all about pressing the button at the right time. In each event the player only gets one attempt.
title: Sporting Decathlon

description:
Strategic Command is a strategy game for two players that is played on a map with five islands. Each player has three bases which produce units: an army base, a naval base and a capital. The army and naval bases can only produce their own kind of units while the capital can produce both. To win the game a player has to take control of the capital of the enemy.

The game is entirely played with joysticks. Holding down the fire button passes control from one base to another and pulling the joystick and pressing the button produces a unit that corresponds to the direction of the pull. There are sixteen types of units and they are deployed in task forces of up to three units. Task forces can then be moved around the screen and when getting close to an enemy combat will occur. Each unit has an attacking factor and a defensive factor. Each attack will cause the defensive factor of the target to decrease with the attacking factor of the attacker. When it reaches zero the unit is destroyed.

Each player can lay mines through special units, one naval and one army, which each can lay two minefields. An enemy unit that moves over a mine will be completely destroyed. Mines can be removed by moving a minesweeper over them. There are no air units but air power is represented by the ability to reconnoitre enemies. This option appears occasionally and allows the player to see the composition of a task force.

sample_screenshots.caption: Light infantry takes on three tanks
Yellow circle is for selecting unit to reconnoitre

title: Strategic Command

description:
Pub Crawl is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32.

The goal of the game is to visit as many pubs as you can and drink a pint at each one. The game is divided into 12 buildings: 10 of which are pubs, and 1 diner and your home. Each building has an entrance, and the goal is to visit every pub, drink a pint, and return home safely without getting hit by the cars that move vertically or arrested by the police officers who move laterally. Every pint drank makes the game move faster, but this can be slowed down by eating at the diner. If the player returns home safely, they head out for another night of drinking with faster moving dangers. The player starts with 3 lives.
title: Pub Crawl

description:
Quazimodo is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32.

The object of the game is to rescue the princess from the castle. You do this by moving Quazimodo across the castle wall while avoiding numerous dangers including turrets, guards with spears, rocks, and flying arrows. The player can move laterally and jump. There are 4 levels of difficulty, and the player starts with 3 lives, and the game has a total of 10 screens.
title: Quazimodo

description:
Robin Hood is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32.

The wicked Sheriff of Nottingham has imprisoned Maid Marion in his castle. You must guide Robin Hood up the castle wall and collect the key to open the tower door. To hinder your task the Sheriff has deployed magical arrows and floors. In seeing that by some miracle you may overcome these traps, the Sheriff throws down boulders trying to dislodge you from the wall. There are also bags of gold and crowns to be collected. After you rescue Maid Marion, you will enter a bonus stage where Maid Marion drops hearts. The player starts with 3 lives, and it's game over if all are lost.
title: Robin Hood

description:
Cosmic Crusader is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32.

You are the Cosmic Crusader. The sole purpose of your existence is to explore the uncharted depths of the cosmos. You will voyage far into the galaxy mapping each sector and conquering any alien life forms that attack you.

The player moves their spacecraft in an arc at the bottom of the screen and fires perpendicular to the arc. Alien menaces appear from the small spacecraft at the top of the screen, and the player shoots these for points. A counter on the top of the screen shows how many aliens must be destroyed to advance to the next stage. The player has limited shield that can be temporarily activated to protect from incoming alien fire. If the player is hit by alien fire they lose a life and the counter resets.
title: Cosmic Crusader

description:
Ruby Robba is a 1 - 2 player puzzle game.

The object is to steal the precious ruby by deactivating the complex defense system within 60 seconds. Played on a 10 x 10 grid, the player slides a pointer along the sides of the grid, and can push that row or column away from the pointer, with blocks looping back from the opposite side. The goal is to move items, especially the ruby, to the box located at the top left of the screen. A line with a snake, guard, or ruby can not be pushed beyond that special character. Guards and snakes move about occupied spaces and chase after the ruby. Guards tend to protect the level exit, while snakes follow rapidly after the ruby. If the ruby is captured, it's returned to the starting square. Mines move about empty spaces, and blocks, including those containing snakes or guards, can be destroyed by moving them into a mine. The mystery box provides bonus points if moved to the exit point.

sample_screenshots.caption: The Guard is by the Ruby
Starting Puzzle - Single Guard and Snake

title: Ruby Robba

description:
Impossiball! is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32.

Played from the perspective directly behind a ball rolling down a hill, the player must move the ball laterally and jump to avoid falling in pits. The player has 5 jumps per life. Terrain consists of fast and slow moving ground, neutral ground where the player sets the speed, jumping squares, and holes. The player starts with 5 lives, and the goal is to reach the end of the course before 999 time units have passed.

sample_screenshots.caption: Rolling Along a the Fast Track

title: Impossiball!

description:
Juxtaposition: Barons of Ceti V is a graphic adventure for the Dragon 32.

The planet Ceti V is owned by eight fabulously wealthy mining Barons. Between them, they control the Galaxy's prime source of Cetite ore, the fuel for hyperspaceships. The Barons run their planet on feudalistic lines. Their employees, known as servitors, have few rights and no freedom outside the confines of their master's Baronial lands, but they are well paid and well treated. A servitor can easily make his fortune in ten or fifteen years of adult service, after which he is retired to a planet within the Federal Democracy.

The player receives a message via vidphone from their employer Baron White. He is concerned that Baroness Black has been experimenting with the Juxtaposition, a line of dimensional instability that passes through Ceti V. You are tasked with gathering the trust of the other seven Barons by travelling to their fortress and completing a task for them. Then, the player can infiltrate the fortress of Baroness Black, to defeat the Baroness' plans.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and game play is divided between exploring the planet's surface, where all locations are graphically displayed on the screen, and entering locations, where the game reverts to text adventure. All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and there is a save/restore feature.
title: Juxtaposition: Barons of Ceti V

description:
River of Fire is a graphical adventure for the Dragon 32.

You work at a small medical clinic on a volcanic island. The volcano has started to erupt, threatening everyone on the island. You must save the staff and bring yourself to safety. The player explores areas inside the clinic and the nearby environment on the island. All commands are via VERB NOUN entry,

sample_screenshots.caption: On the Slopes of the Volcano

title: River of Fire

description:
Fearless Freddy is a 1-player arcade game.

Fearless Fireman Freddy is bravely climbing the burning office block, collecting the possessions of the surviving people. Freddy can move laterally on platforms, and can descend by falling between floors, or catch a lift to higher levels. Fireballs fall from above, and move about the platforms. The player must avoid these and not fall into cauldrons of fire, while trying to collect all the possessions on the screen to move to the next level. The player has limited time to complete each level, represented by a thermometer that counts upwards to 1,000 degrees. The player starts with 5 lives represented by water buckets, with a new one awarded every 10,000 points. There are two levels of difficulty representing different level designs.

sample_screenshots.caption: Central Lift and Lots of Platforms

title: Fearless Freddy

description:
Star Swoop is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32.

The player controls a small spacecraft, as they try to eliminate the incoming Zargon fleet. The player's ship moves horizontally at the bottom of the screen and fires directly forwards. Zargon ships appear rapidly from the top of the screen and begin to swoop about. As the game progresses, enemy ships become faster and return fire more frequently. The player can lose 3 vessels before game over.
title: Star Swoop

description:
Tea Time is a 1-player arcade game.

The player controls a teapot that can be moved in all directions. In odd-numbered levels, the player tries to catch falling tea drops in their kettle, and when the kettle is full dump the tea in the mug at the bottom left of the screen. A hammer chases the player about the screen, which will shatter the kettle and cost a life if hit. Once the required tea drops are caught, the player moves to the next level. On even numbered levels, sugar cubes fall from above, and if the player takes 2 hits, they lose a tea pot.

After completing an even-numbered level, the player enters the pantry. There, the player can only move horizontally, and must pick up all bonus icons. If the player falls too far, their kettle will smash.
title: Tea Time

description:
4D Romik Cube is a 1 player puzzle game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player attempts to solve a randomized Rubik's Cube by selecting the axis and direction of rotation of the puzzle. The cube is graphically displayed on the screen with only 3 sides displayed.
title: 4D Romik Cube

description:
Air Assault is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls a crippled helicopter that moves back and forth above the deserted city of Kroywen, flying slightly lower each crossing. The helicopter drops bombs, and tries to destroy the buildings. The goal is to clear a pathway that allows the player to vertically land their helicopter on a flat piece of land. If the helicopter strikes a building or is caught up in their own explosions it's game over.
title: Air Assault

description:
Amazing is a 1-player maze game for the Dragon 32/64 designed to teach coordination for children.

The player chooses from five levels of difficulty to navigate a square through a randomized maze from the top left to the bottom right. If the player touches a wall they lose the challenge.
title: Amazing

alternate_titles.title: All Because the Lady Loves Milky Chocs.

description:
And All Because... is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player must go through a number of arcade sequences to try to get chocolate to their beloved lady's home before she arrives. Includes a driving sequence, running, horse riding, motor cycle riding and jumping, hang gliding, skiing, dangling from a ski lift, and parachuting. Each short arcade sequence is timed, and there are 2 levels of difficulty.
title: And All Because...

description:
Attack is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls a small space ship that moves in all directions, fires directly forwards, and flies above the ground on a screen that scrolls to the left and right. The player is attacked by slow moving alien ships which when hit become briefly vulnerable. During this time the player must pick them up, or else they become rapidly moving dangers that veer directly towards the player. When in their fast moving mode, the player can shoot these vessels again to reset them to vulnerable. The player starts with 3 lives, and must defeat a set number of enemies to progress to the next level.

sample_screenshots.caption: Engaged by a Fast Moving Enemy

title: Attack

description:
Bandit is a 1-player slot machine game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player spins 3 reels on a slot machine, and wins money by scoring 3 in a row or cherries. The player starts with $250, and breaks the bank at $1000. Each spin costs $10. Intermittently, the player can save a reel for an additional spin.
title: Bandit

description:
Sniper is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls a gunsight, and shoots targets that appear in windows by positioning a crosshair over the target. On each level the player starts with 10 points, and gains 5 points for a hit, but loses 2 points if the target isn't hit in time. After reaching 50 or 100 points (depending on game length), the player advances to a harder level with less time to hit the target and more challenging gunsight control. There are two levels of difficulty, and the player can choose a short or long game.
title: Sniper

description:
Blockbuster Quiz is a 2-player trivia game for the Dragon 32/64 based upon the 80s TV game show Blockbuster.

A game board containing 25 hexagons arranged in a 5 x 5 set each containing a different letter (no X) is displayed. Players choose a hexagon, and are presented with a trivia question where the answer starts with that letter. The player who answers the question correctly receives that space. The first person to score 5 in a row wins. There are over 500 trivia questions to choose from.
title: Blockbuster Quiz

description:
Blockbuster Quiz 2 is a 2-player trivia game for the Dragon 32/64 based upon the 80s TV game show Blockbuster.

A game board containing 25 hexagons arranged in a 5 x 5 set each containing a different letter (no X) is displayed. Players choose a hexagon, and are presented with a trivia question where the answer starts with that letter. The player who answers the question correctly receives that space. The first person to score 5 in a row wins. There are over 500 trivia questions to choose from.
title: Blockbuster Quiz 2

description:
The Bomb is a text adventure for the Dragon 32/64

Before he died, the mad scientist Alfred Twit constructed an immensely powerful bomb which will soon detonate, destroying the entire world. Only one person is allowed in the area of the house, or the bomb will detonate, and the player has volunteered. There are nine pieces of bomb-defusing equipment inside Twit's house, and the player will need to find them to defuse the bomb. The player has a limited number of moves to solve the adventure, and there are 8 levels of difficulty which define the time available and the number of pieces of bomb defusing equipment required.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and there is no save/restore feature.
title: The Bomb

description:
Bopswizzle is a arcade and puzzle game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player has come to search for the three legendary black pearls of the ancients which are hidden within the City of Ages. The city is home to several nasties, including: Gloops, jellified blobs of protoplasm whose very touch is deadly, Smoochers, giant lips who descend onto their prey and kiss them to death, Wiggles, tiny worm-like creatures who burrow their way through everything, Bobwangles, furry creatures whose chief delight is stealing hair, and Yerkles, sneaky creatures who will catch the player and drop them into the nearest midden.

Each turn, the player will encounter a special event. They might encounter the Smoochers, in which case the player has 3 tries to correctly guess the right number from 1 - 10. Failure to do so loses the game. If encountering the Wiggles, the player has 2 tries to guess a number from 1 to 6, and is given a hint after the first number if it's higher or lower. The Yerkles sends the player to an arcade sequence where they must navigate through a moving passageway. The player may encounter gold, the Bird of Paradise who offers clues, or may find one of the black pearls. If the player can recover all 3 black pearls they are victorious.
title: Bopswizzle

description:
Brock's Kingdom is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls Brock, who travels through a number of interconnected rooms to gather treasure and avoid monsters. Brock is armed with a gun that has very limited ammo, which can be picked up around the maze. The gun can only fire horizontally left or right. There are a total of 50 rooms to explore with the goal to explore all rooms. The player starts with limited energy, and loses some if they contact walls, demons, spiders, or ghosts. The player receives score for areas explored and items picked up.
title: Brock's Kingdom

description:
Chateau is a menu-driven text adventure for the Dragon 32/64.

The player enters the old chateau where the Count who lived there died. He hid all his worldly goods in the house including a hoard of treasure. Each floor of the chateau is divided into a 5 x 5 grid, and an in game map tracks the current position and floor. All commands are via menu, and the player can move to a new room, open a door, explore the area for treasure (or encounter traps), check their status, or review the floor plan. The player needs to collect specific items which allow them to explore new areas or combat monsters. Failure in combat or stumbling over traps can cause the player injury, and if health drops to 0 it's game over.

sample_screenshots.caption: Need a Lamp to Enter the Cellar

title: Chateau

description:
Chess is a 1-player board game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player competes against the computer in chess. There are multiple difficulty levels, and pieces are individually selected and moved using a flashing cursor.
title: Chess

description:
The Chocolate Factory is a 2 - 6 player business managerial game for the Dragon 32.

Each player takes control of a chocolate factory, with the goal to make and sell chocolate bars for profit. The goal is to make the most money after all turns are spent, reach $10,000,000, or to be the last company to remain in solvency. Each player starts with a net worth of $50,000; a factory worth $20,000 and $30,000 in cash. Each turn, the player is given a prediction of total market size and total chocolate making capacity of all companies. The player can spend money each turn to increase their chocolate bar making capacity, and the player must spend on overhead and the cost of warehousing unsold chocolate. The player must also purchase vans to deliver chocolate bars, which have an initial cost, running costs, and a limited lifespan. Staff must be purchased to sell chocolate bars, and advertising can also be purchased. Negative events like fire and accidents can occur, and the player can buy insurance to cover these potential costs. At the end of each turn, interest is charged on a negative balance and paid for a positive cash balance.

Numerous gameplay options can be set, including: market prediction accuracy, interest rates, inflation levels, strikes, absenteeism, boom market, heatwave problems, and cocoa supply problems.

At the end of each turn, the player's total expenses and profits are calculated.
title: The Chocolate Factory

description:
Clowns is a series of 3 arcade games featuring clowns for the Dragon 32.

In Catch, the player controls a clown with a net on a stick, and can move this laterally to catch balls that roll off a platform from the top right of the screen. Balls come in different colors, and the player loses the game if they drop a red ball.

In Juggle, the player controls a clown with 2 arms, and both arms can be moved left or right simultaneously to try to catch the balls that bounce between the clown's hands. If 3 balls are dropped, it's game over. Every 300 points ball speed increases up to 2400 points.
title: Clowns

description:
Combat Air Patrol is a 1-player flight simulator and combat game for the Dragon 32.

The player has been assigned to fly the Royal Air Force's new interceptor the Tornado. The mission is to fly the skies in search of enemy Russian F-25 Foxbats and shoot them down. The aircraft is armed with 2 sidewinder missiles and a cannon with 90 shots. The cannon can shoot down aircraft directly ahead, and the missiles can destroy aircraft behind. The player can control their landing gear, airbrakes, wing sweep, and can enter a refueling or landing sequence. The cockpit displays the player's front view, rear view, and current plane condition.

There are 3 sequences of game play. The refueling sequence, where the player must manuever the nose of their aircraft to the end of the drogue. The landing sequene can commence below 2500 ft, where the player attempts to safely navigate their plane towards and land on the runway. Finally, there is the combat sequence, where the player can dogfight enemy aircraft which appear in the rearview mirror. The player must avoid destroying friendly American aircraft.
title: Combat Air Patrol

description:
Colossal Cave a faithful adaptation of the original Colossal Cave classic text adventure by Crowther and Woods. The objective is to explore the titular cave and gather as much treasure as possible in order to get the highest score possible.

The player has to deal with random dangers including dwarf attacks, the vending machine maze, and a pirate that can steal the player's treasures.
title: Colossal Cave

description:
Crib is a 1-player versus computer graphical cribbage game for the Dragon 32.

The player competes against the computer opponent in a game of Cribbage. Each player receives 6 cards at the beginning of the game, 2 of which are discarded to the crib. Players play their 4 cards, 1 at a time, and score points for specific scores and runs. The final hand score is divided between cards in hand and the active card. One player receives the crib each hand.
title: Crib

description:
The Crinklewood Incident is a text adventure for the Dragon 32.

Life is pretty good being the sole owner of the Vole-Strangler millions. You, Arnold Q. Vole-Strangler (the 14th) lie relaxed in a padded cell recalling the sumptuousness of Castle Vole-Strangler and the verdant lushness of Vole-Strangler Acres. Things haven't been so ripping since the nubile Cynthia Smythe-Drongo ran off with that Spaniard from Llandudno. After all, apart from playing a mean pair of castanets, what could he offer that the Vole-Strangler empire couldn't? Still, no point in worrying about it, there are more important problems to consider. For example, what to do until the launderette opens? Of course, the very thing! Why not pop out and find the HOLY GRAIL? It won't take long to get there and back again.

All locations, directions, and items are displayed on the screen, and all commands are entered via typing VERB NOUN commands. The player's health and current wallet is also displayed. There are 5 levels of difficulty, and the player can encounter random combats. During combat, the player and enemy take turns attacking, and if the player loses they are sent to the hospital. There are also random events like alien abductions and police encounters which move the player on the map. There is a save/restore feature.
title: The Cricklewood Incident

description:
Crusader is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

In quest for the Holy Grail, the player must overcome seven increasingly difficult stages to reach their goal of the inner sanctum. The player can move laterally and jump, and must avoid deadly dwarves and scorpions, cross enchanted lakes, swing over deadly pits, and scale city walls. The player starts with 4 lives, and it's game over when all are lost. 100 points are gained for each screen completed.
title: Crusader

description:
Danger Island is a text adventure for the Dragon 32/64.

The player has arrived on Danger Island, with the goal of finding the treasure chest and safely escaping. The player must navigate dangers including angry natives and dense forests. A poisonous snake appears randomly to bite the player, and they must obtain the antidote from the local marketplace.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and there is no save/restore feature.
title: Danger Island

description:
Death Cruise is a 1 - 4 player text adventure and puzzle for the Dragon 32/64.

There is murder afoot on the high seas. It is the maiden voyage of the luxury liner Pacific 1. Amongst the passengers is His Royal Highness King David, whose security is the player's responsibility. Five days into the voyage, miles from the nearest shore, the player receives a telegram that the fanatical Mr. Sinister has brought a bomb aboard the vessel and disguised himself as a passenger or a member of the crew. To save the king, crew, and passengers, the player must find the bomb, the room where the detonator is planted, and identify Mr. Sinister.

The goal is to successfully identify Mr Sinister, which of the 25 rooms on the Pacific 1 has the bomb detonator, and what item is masquerading as the bomb. The player travels between 25 rooms spread over 5 decks of the ship. All commands are via text input, and the screen displays the deck, location, objects and people in the room, and items and people being carried. There are 2 separate programs with different rules: a single player version where the player has limited turns to solve the puzzle, and a mutliplayer game where the first person to solve the puzzle wins. The player can carry 1 - 2 items and take a single person with them. The player can encounter an assassin, and if they don't have bullets, it's game over. Once the player has determined the crime, they can accuse by being in the correct room with the correct person and item. If they are incorrect, the game is lost.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Meet Characters in the Lounge

title: Death Cruise

description:
Diffuse is an arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player must defuse a bomb located in an underground maze. The bomb is represented by a red square, the player a white square. The player has limited time to reach and defuse the bomb, and may have to drill through walls to reach the bomb. Each drilling attempt costs time. Upon reaching the bomb, the player must cut the correct wire to deactivate the explosive. There are 5 levels of game play.
title: Diffuse

description:
Dominoes is a 1-player versus computer board game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player with the highest double starts the game. Players take turns laying tiles on either the left or the right branch that numerically match the exposed number. If the player can't go, they must pass, pick up a tile, and either go again or hand the play to their opponent depending on game type. Game play continues until there are no tiles left to pick up. All tiles are graphically displayed on the board. Each player receives points depending on the value of the tiles left in their hand at the end of the game. There are 6 levels of computer difficulty.
title: Dominoes

description:
Dragon Chess is a implementation of chess versus the computer for the Dragon 32/64.

There are 6 levels of computer difficulty, and input is by typing piece coordinates. Command options include: Flip to switch positions of white and black, Alter to set a custom board, Clear to clear the board, Level to change computer difficulty, Hint to get a move recommendation, List to see all moves during the game, Resume to return to the game, New to start a new game, Swap to switch position with the computer, and Exit to quit the game.
title: Dragon Chess

description:
Dragon Darts is a 1 - 6 player sports game for the Dragon 32/64.

Players take turns throwing darts to reach 301, 501, 1001, or a custom score. There are 9 levels of difficulty, which determine how long a player has to move the aims at the top and left side of the screen to direct their throw. Games start by throwing doubles.
title: Dragon Darts

description:
Dragonfly: Flight Simulator is a 1-player flight simulator for the Dragon 32.

The player takes off and navigates their small aircraft from Norwich airport to fly circuits or to Hethel Air Force Base. Played from a 1st person perspective, the player can set the wind strength and starting fuel. A map of local terrain is available, and the player can control their altitude, flaps, undercart, and power.
title: Dragonfly: Fight Simulator

description:
Dragonfly II: Hi-Res. Flight Simulator is a graphically updated version of Dragonfly: Flight Simulator for the Dragon 32/64.

The player takes off and navigates their small aircraft from Norwich airport to fly circuits or to Hethel Air Force Base. Played from a 1st person perspective, the player can set the wind strength and starting fuel. A map of local terrain is available, and the player can control their attitude, flaps, undercart, and power.
title: Dragonfly II: Hi-Res. Flight Simulator

description:
Dragon Golf is a 1-player golf game for the Dragon 32/64.

Each hole is graphically displayed on the screen from overhead, and includes fairways, rough, water, trees, bunkers, and out of bounds. The player chooses which club to use to choose how far to shoot, but the computer automatically aims. In putting, the player chooses the putting power, but once again the computer aims. The player can choose their handicap, and ask for assistance with a specific aspect of golf: hooking, slicing, poor distance, bunker shots, or putting. A scoreboard tracks score between holes.
title: Dragon Golf

description:
Dragon Hawk is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls a small character at the bottom of the screen who moves laterally, and can fire directly upwards. A large hawk flies from the top of the screen and attempts to capture Freddie at the bottom left of the screen and carry him to the top right. The player completes a level by shooting the small flies that roam the screen, or shooting the hawk to prevent it from capturing Freddie. After shooting the hawk, Freddie falls to the bottom of the screen, and the player must grab the basket at the bottom right of the screen and position it under Freddie before he hits the bottom. Small orbs float around the screen that become aggressive Space Invaders if shot. The player starts with 3 lives.
title: Dragon Hawk

description:
Dragon Mountain is a text adventure for the Dragon 32/64.

The player must search underground in a large series of caves to find the dragon's treasure. The player encounters dangerous elves, demons, and the dreaded dragon. Numerous item-related puzzles need to be solved.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and there is no save/restore feature.
title: Dragon Mountain

description:
Dragonslayer is a text adventure for the Dragon 32/64.

The player is on an adventure to find the sacred treasure of kings long ago. It is guarded by a dragon and other more subtle dangers. The player is alone on a small swamp infested island, and the player must hunt for the entrance to the dungeon and avoid all the dangerous traps about.

All commands are via VERB NOUN entry, and there is no save/restore feature.
title: Dragonslayer

description:
Dragon Trek is a strategy game for the Dragon 32/64.

As captain of the Starship Enterprise, the player is tasked with ridding the galaxy of a specific number of enemy vessels. Starbases are available for refuelling and repairing, and the player has a total of 5 years to complete their mission. The total galaxy is divided into an 8 x 8 grid of 64 quadrants. The Enterprise is equipped with short range scanners which show items available in that quadrant, and long range scanners which show presence of items in surrounding quadrants. The player must track their energy levels, which are used for phasers and propulsion, and their shields which protect from enemy attack. The helm is used to plot course and move within or between quadrants. A limited number of torpedoes can assist with destroying enemy vessels. Ultimately, the player can choose to self-destruct to prevent their vessel from falling into enemy hands.

The player can choose from 5 difficulty levels, and set their own self-destruct code.
title: Dragon Trek

description:
Dragrunner is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

Help super sleuth Sidney make as many journeys across the factory floor as he can. The floor has six counter-rotating conveyor belts, which are loaded with an increasing number of deadly radioactive components each trip. Laser droids patrol the floors between the belts. The player moves in the cardinal directions, and can shoot out the incoming laser droids that approach from the sides of the screen. A gauge at the top of the screen tracks how many lasers were shot, and if too many are destroyed, the entire walls and floors become electrified, and the player loses a life. The player starts with five lives.
title: Dragrunner

description:
The Dream Machine is a text adventure for the Dragon 32/64.

A sudden disturbance in the fabric of space caused a warp. The player finds themself in a dimly-lit laboratory. In the centre of the lab is a large machine. Suddenly a face appears in mid-air. "Help me!" it cries, "I have been caught by a devil. Use my dream machine and rescue me!" Then, the face is replaced by a sinister, horned figure which scowls, "If you want the professor back then bring me 4 animals: a salamander, a basilisk, a minotaur and a golem."

The player must search through four different areas, transported by the Dream Machine, to find the four creatures. The player can also explore the old Victorian home where the machine lies in the basement.

All command are via VERB NOUN entry. There is a save/restore feature.

sample_screenshots.caption: In the Kitchen of the Old House

title: The Dream Machine

description:
Drone Datatank is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player's mission as a Free System Warrior is to seek out and destroy the evil Rom Guardian. The player must search through the countless memory tunnels and grid zones, while avoiding error bugs and defending themselves against attacks from the Guardian's drone fleet.

Taking place within the computer, the player controls a M.K. Type Datatank, which can accelerate, brake, super-thrust, and fire dual logic cannons and pulse lasers. The player controls the tank from a 1st-person perspective, and tries to blast incoming enemies. The player can choose to start in four different types of sectors, which determines the enemies encountered.
title: Drone Datatank

description:
Dungeons of Death is a text adventure for multiple systems.

The player explores the titular Dungeons of Death to find all of the hidden treasures. The player encounters a number of enemies, including a wight and a spectre who they can engage in combat. The player can gather weapons, armor, and other useful items. Each item has a value in gp, and the player is awarded a final score for items collected when they leave the dungeon. In combat, the player and monster take turns exchanging blows, losing hit points as combat progresses.
title: Dungeons of Death

description:
Everest is a managerial strategy game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player organizes a spring or autumn climbing expedition to summit Mount Everest, Lhotse, or Nuptse. At the beginning of the expedition the player must choose the amount of food, tents, oxygen, rope, and ladders to bring, with a total of 1800 lbs of space available. The player has a total of 6 climbers, and each day the player can move each climber to a higher or lower camp. This climber can carry a certain amount of resources, which are needed to keep the climbers healthy. The goal is to get enough resources to the highest camp in the minimal number of days to allow the hikers to summit the mountain. Hikers must have resources to avoid becoming injured during the climb. Random weather events and accidents can affect the climbers.
title: Everest

description:
Fingers is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls a thief who trys to gather all the keys on a level in order to break into a safe. The thief must jump between platforms, avoid police cars, navigate moving platforms, and be careful about platforms that break underneath him permanently. There are 5 levels of difficulty, and the player starts with 3 lives.
title: Fingers

description:
Fireball is a 1-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.

The player controls a small character who travels across platforms and climbs up and down ladders in a burning building. They must avoid and destroy fireballs over six levels, where each level has an additional fireball. The fireballs will chase the player around the level. The character can dig holes to temporarily trap fireballs, and then can grab and drop a rock on the fireball to extinguish it. The player starts with three lives, and loses a life if caught by a fireball or if they fall off a ladder or a platform.

sample_screenshots.caption: I Fell in my Own Hole

title: Fireball

description:
Flag is a 1- or 2-player arcade game for the Dragon 32/64.
